title: Artificial Intelligence: Concepts & Applications
description: A progressive exploration of Artificial Intelligence, from foundational theories to modern applications and ethical considerations.

paragraphs.summary: An overview of Artificial Intelligence (AI) as a field of computer science dedicated to creating systems that can perform tasks typically requiring human intelligence.
A brief timeline of key milestones, thinkers, and periods in the development of Artificial Intelligence, from early concepts to modern breakthroughs.
Categorization of AI systems: Artificial Narrow Intelligence (ANI), Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), and Artificial Superintelligence (ASI).
A test of a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior equivalent to, or indistinguishable from, that of a human.
Fundamental AI techniques for solving problems, including defining states, operators, and goals, and employing search algorithms.
Exploring uninformed search (e.g., BFS, DFS) and informed search (e.g., A*, Greedy) strategies for navigating problem spaces.
Methods for encoding knowledge about the world in a form that a computer system can utilize to solve complex tasks.
Using propositional and predicate logic to represent knowledge and perform deductive reasoning in AI systems.
AI systems designed to emulate the decision-making ability of a human expert in a specific, narrow domain.
A subfield of AI where systems learn patterns and make predictions from data without being explicitly programmed for each task.
ML paradigm where the algorithm learns from a labeled dataset, mapping inputs to known outputs (e.g., classification, regression).
ML paradigm where the algorithm learns patterns from an unlabeled dataset (e.g., clustering, dimensionality reduction).
ML paradigm where an agent learns to make a sequence of decisions by trying to maximize a cumulative reward signal in an environment.
A supervised learning method that uses a tree-like graph of decisions and their possible consequences for classification or regression.
Computational models inspired by the structure and function of biological neural networks, forming the basis of deep learning.
A subset of machine learning based on artificial neural networks with multiple layers (deep architectures) to learn complex data representations.
Functions used in neural networks to determine the output of a node given an input or set of inputs (e.g., Sigmoid, ReLU, Tanh).
A widely used algorithm for training artificial neural networks by efficiently computing the gradient of the loss function.
A class of deep neural networks, most commonly applied to analyzing visual imagery, using convolutional layers to detect features.
A class of artificial neural networks where connections between nodes form a directed graph along a temporal sequence, allowing them to process sequences of inputs.
A subfield of AI concerned with the interaction between computers and humans using natural language.
The process of segmenting text into smaller units called tokens (words, subwords, or characters) for NLP tasks.
Using NLP techniques to identify and extract subjective information (opinions, emotions, attitudes) from text data.
The task of automatically translating text or speech from one natural language to another using computational models.
A deep learning model architecture excelling in NLP tasks, characterized by its use of self-attention mechanisms to weigh the importance of different parts of input data.
Transformer-based neural networks trained on vast amounts of text data, capable of generating human-like text, answering questions, and more.
A field of AI that enables computers to derive meaningful information from digital images or videos.
The task of identifying and classifying objects, scenes, or activities within an image.
Identifying and locating multiple objects within an image, often by drawing bounding boxes around them.
AI systems capable of generating new content, such as images, text, audio, or synthetic data, often based on patterns learned from existing data.
A class of machine learning frameworks where two neural networks (generator and discriminator) contest with each other in a zero-sum game framework.
The intersection of AI and engineering concerned with the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.
Algorithms used in robotics and autonomous systems to find an optimal path between two points while avoiding obstacles.
The study of moral issues and societal impacts arising from the development and deployment of artificial intelligence.
Systematic errors or prejudices in AI algorithms or data that result in unfair or discriminatory outcomes.
Methods and techniques in AI aimed at ensuring that the decisions and predictions made by AI systems can be understood by humans.
Research and practices focused on preventing unintended harmful consequences from advanced AI systems.
The process of cleaning, transforming, and organizing raw data into a suitable format for machine learning models.
The process of using domain knowledge to select and transform raw data variables into features that better represent the underlying problem to predictive models.
Techniques and metrics used to assess the performance and accuracy of machine learning models on unseen data.
Overfitting occurs when a model learns training data too well, performing poorly on new data. Underfitting occurs when a model is too simple to capture underlying patterns.
The process of selecting the optimal set of hyperparameters (configuration settings external to the model) for a learning algorithm.
Machine learning techniques that combine the predictions of multiple base models to improve overall performance and robustness.
Techniques for reducing the number of input variables (features) in a dataset while preserving essential information.
Unsupervised learning methods for grouping a set of objects such that objects in the same group (cluster) are more similar to each other than to those in other groups.
The identification of rare items, events, or observations which raise suspicions by differing significantly from the majority of the data.
AI systems that predict the 'rating' or 'preference' a user would give to an item, used in e-commerce, media streaming, etc.
Applications of AI in the medical field, including diagnostics, personalized medicine, drug discovery, and robotic surgery.
Use of AI in financial services for algorithmic trading, fraud detection, credit scoring, risk management, and customer service.
Applications of AI in video games for creating intelligent non-player characters (NPCs), procedural content generation (PCG), game balancing, and player modeling.
Speculations and ongoing research regarding the future development of AI, including the pursuit of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) and its potential societal impacts.
